text: if you want to think of the stomach is
kind of a balloon as it kind of empties
out sometimes you'll hear that sloshing
so why does our stomach growl when we're
hungry or why do we hear those rumblings
in our belly and so basically what we're
hearing is the motion of the muscles
that contract in our digestive system
which includes the stomach the small
bowel in the colon and what you're kind
of hearing is the sloshing around to the
fluids a little bit of the air passing
by as well and when your stomach is
empty or for your small bowel is empty
there's no food in there or anything to
buffer the sound so it sounds a little
bit louder as far as your stomach
shrinking it's not necessarily shrinking
I like to call it as more of a deflating
but it usually doesn't make a noise per
se if you want to think of the stomach
is kind of a balloon in its resting
state it's like a floppy balloon and
when it gets filled with water air gas
food then it just kind of keeps
expanding but as it kind of empties out
sometimes you'll hear that sloshing
sometimes you'll hear kind of the
passing of the gas from as it passes
from the stomach into the small bowel
the growling is just more the basically
just the motion of everything sloshing
around in there because you're empty or
because the stomach is empty there's no
food in there to buffer the sounds so it
seems like they're louder those sounds
that we hear in the digestive tract as
physicians are very important because
then there's normal bowel sounds that we
like to listen to in normal healthy
people but if people are critically ill
those changes in the bowel sounds make a
big deal of difference if we're able to
diagnose obstruction and any other
medical problem that might be causing
those changes in the in the
gastrointestinal sounds
